reviews.review: Durbar Square. Hanuman Dhoka is a palace of Malla Kings and the Shah dynasty. The name is given after the stone sculpture of the Hanuman. Hanuman is a hindu monkey god which sits near the entrance of the palace. The museum inside the Hanuman Dhoka exhibits the ornaments, furnitures, coins collections, weapons, armors etc in the display of the museum.
the historical Dokha. it is a historical dokha which included a lot of temple amazing architecture and beautiful location, it just loved it
Nice Place to visit. Nice Place to visit during Kathmandu tour. Symbol of Rich Culture and Heritage. Little Crowdy area , but still loved this place.
old tempal. hanuman dhoka temple is one of the old durbar ans nice and old cultural carvin but little damage fram big disaster

Lots of history. Loved this place which is the Kathmandu´s royal palace. Lots of history going back all the way to Licchavi Period around the 4th to 8th Centuries. Unfortunately alot of damage has been done due to the Earthquake of 2015. Loved the courtyards and the surrounds and the museum. Well worth a visit when you go to Kathmandu.
Still quaint. Damages is done during the earthquake, Nasal chawk and Lohan chawk are still open, but not the museums.

Great World Heritage Site left unbuilt after earthquake :(. It was one of the most famous attraction in Kathmandu valley at center of the city with palaces, museums and courtyards which was severly damaged by Gorkha earthquake. The rebuilding process is so slow or not at all. Very sad to see this beautiful site like this.
great. hanuman dhoka is one of the oldest heritage tourist tawn near in side durbar squere little damace fram big dissaster

After quake work in progress but still a must see. As most durbar squares in the valley of Kathmandu also this one is a huge restoration work in progress after the quake of 2015. What survived and what's been restored is stunningly beautiful and you really should not miss it.

Could have been better. Been one year yet many outstanding restructuring to do. I guess if funds are managed and manpower is organized, the city will stand up again as its a beautiful history behind this place.

Beautiful Architecture.    It has a history hidden in it. Although, last year's earthquake did a terrible loss to whole Nepal. So was this  place also affected. But still you can go and feel the place. The Kumari  temple is a beautiful example of Nevari art. This place has a small shopping area as well. If you are not a local then you need to pay some fee to enter here. Worth a visit!

Beautiful place to hang out. Hanuman Doka   Its a must visit place. It has a history hidden in it. Although, last year's earthquake did a terrible loss to whole Nepal. So was this  place also affected. But still you can go and feel the place. The Kumari  temple is a beautiful example of Nevari art. I would suggest that before going to this place try to search it in internet so that you get the actual idea of the place. This place has a small shopping area as well. There is a entry fee for everybody except the locals. Worth a visit!
Visit once!!!. The most exciting point of Hanuman Dhoka is The Sexy Temple. Don't Miss this one. Also Live God Kumari. Central of Kathmandu and easy to rich there.

Nice place to hang out and know the Brief history of the Shah Monarchism.. If you would like to know the brief history of Nepal then this is the best place you can get knowledge. i cannot ignore the fact that it has been effected by the quake 2015 but i was happy to know practically that only some portion has been effected.

Damaged, but worth the visit.. Although seriously damaged by the earthquake I would recommend visiting to see the scale of damage and to put money into restoring it. Entrance fee of NPR1000 or USD$10. The rest of the site is also worth a look.
In ruins now.. It's a sad sight now to see this temple in ruins. Hard even to imagine what it was like before. Look up some photos before you go.

even post -quake worth a visit. Hanuman Dhoka has long been Kathmandu's gem and crowning glory. Many of the buildings and temples were destroyed or seriously damaged by the earthquake of April 25, 2015, and it will be a while before rebuilding is completed. Nonetheless visitors should still go see what is left, and get a sense of the whole area. The Kumari Temple is a beautiful example of classical Newar art and hasn't been damaged significantly. Neither the magnificent Black Bhairab nor the screened in White Bhairab were damaged and are still quite literally awesome. Plus, it is just the general atmosphere of the place that has always been, and still is, magical. If you don''t have time for anything else in Kathmandu, definitely visit Hanuman Dhoka. Mush better than Thamel!
history is here. there is so much to see, learn, taste, hear, smell .. this is the place to spend a long morning walk-around.

Hanuman Dhoka. As with all of Durbar Square, the area is well worth visiting and the people are incredible. There are shops and local artisans everywhere. Just know that the buildings have been severely damaged and are in the process of being rebuilt right now.
Good food. It was nice to enjoy brunch at the place which we preferred to have typical Asian food. We enjoyed the vegetable curry and rice, the country made pickle was greatly enjoyed. Had great time

The heart of Kathmandu. Beautiful architecture.. The most important Kathmandu square with many important buildings, temples and local life. Buddhism and Hinduisim. Some building were destroyed after devasting earthquake and another ones are collapsed Durbar square is so beautiful with many important buildings to see and to enjoy.

Laid waste by the earthquake. The complex, as per tourist literature, was built between the 12th and 18th century. The place is the where kings of Nepal are coronated. Important ministers of the royal court had added temples in honour of various deities over time. The place is also home to the Living Goddess Kumari. However, much of this UNESCO World Heritage site was destroyed during the earthquake of Apr 2015. As on date there remains a lot to be done to restore the precinct. Many of the remaining structures have been shored up for support.
Badly damaged.. Badly damaged and surrounded by many similarly damaged or precarious buildings, which detracts from the experience.

Heavily Damaged - But don't let that stop you going. I did read a number of reviews before writing this and visited end of April, and somewhat mystified at some comments. The area has definitely been heavily damaged by the earthquake, but that does not stop one gaining an appreciation of what it was at the peak of its grandeur. There is still a significant amount that is undamaged, about the same that has sustained minor damage and clearly more that has been severely damaged. Restoration is slow and perhaps not as "tourists" would want, but "travellers" understand the difficulties such huge "force majeure" brings. The area is still magnificent and taking in the substantive architecture that remains provides amazing snapshot of the past.
Staggering. This is one of the must see places in Kathmandu. Make time for it but be aware that a lot has been damaged by the earthquake last year.
Stunnning. Visited here right before the earthquake that hit Nepal. It was better to see in person than photos. It was a humbling experience to be able to see Nepal.

Leisure Time With Friends. before earthquake and after earthquake it changed in looks but the guest for this area and their love to this area still same city of temple and premises of history really good time i have ever spend herewill go again and again
Very Old Hindu Pilgrimage Site. Located in the heart of Kathmandu... Very Busy.. Always Crowded ... Although severely damaged in last Earth Quake but nice to visit...

Massive loss Heritage. The area was highly hit by the earthquake exactly a year ago. People who have visited before and after earthquake, they can feel the magnitude of the effects. After loosing two temples including Kasthamandap from which the name of the capital - Kathmandu was formed, was also destroyed totally. Many parts were damaged as a result, some areas are still restricted to enter for safety reasons. However the visitors are encouraged to come and visit the area as you can see around both remaining monuments and to feel the vibrations of the earthquake that still remain in the area.
In need of repair.. This is part of Durbar Square which you pay 1000 NPR to enter.AU$12. There are a lot of different temples there, desperately in need of repair after earthquake. Lots of touts.

Sad, very sad. The site is not worth visiting at the moment.. The earthquake destroyed this area. It is not worth visiting until the Govt of Nepal makes an effort to restore the site. Meanwhile they charge 1000NR to enter.
Better off going to Swambhu, Boudha, or Patans Durbar Square which is more intact.
It is not even a shadow of its former self. Unfortunate, but true.

Fascinating History. This is part of the larger Durbar Square area which once upon a time housed many amazing buildings and monuments. I am lucky to have witnessed the architectural wonder way back in 1997 and again recently in 2015. The detailing in the architecture is superb and you could spend ages walking round examining every inch and still be in awe. The only down side for me though was the street peddlers who don't seem to give you a minute chasing after you selling their wares. Hanuman Dhoka durbar is in Kathmandu durbar square. There used to be several ancient buildings in Kathmandu Durbar square. Hanuman Dhoka got its name from the statue of monkey god Hanuman at the entrance of the palace. Alas all this is now a thing of past. Just within few paces from the Hanuman’s idol near entrance, used to be a stone inscription of king Pratap Malla which was written in 14 languages including Urdu, English and French. There used to be another temple of Shwet Bhairav that remains closed except during Indra Jatra. All that is left now is ruins. Nature has its own way of turning things up and down and I feel sorry for the localities that lost their lives in the massive earthquake.

what a terrible the earthquake destroyed everything. what a terrible the earthquake destroyed everything, hope it will be rebuilt soon, not only this place all other historical monuments are collapsed

Secure Entrance .. Hanuman Dhoka, Entrance to palace which is secure by God Hanuman. Lovely place that is surrounded by beautiful temples and golden gate entrance to ancient palace of 14th century of Malla dynasty. Near to the main entrance a huge statue of Hanuman on 6ft stage that statue is covered with red cloth. Every morning many people come here to worship different goddess and god around here. This is a fascinating place for travelers, there is entrance fee for tourist.
Needs major repairs to retain its former glory. Suffered badly in the earthquake. Presumably will be rebuilt.Lots of other things to see and do in the square, though.
Wonderful Historical Place.. Even After the Devastating Earthquake, this place is still very beautiful. I reckn everybody to visit this place which is I must say a piece of Heaven on earth.
Nice place. This entire campus is very nice with lot of interesting things to see. One major problem is the beggars, many is number and they keep you following
A must visit place in Kathmandu. This World Heritage Site is so interesting, with lots to see and learn. Beautiful architecture with incredible carvings and stone work.

must Visit place in Kathmandu Nepal. Pashupatinath Temple is the biggest pilgrimage of Hindus and regarded as the most sacred temple of Hindus in the world. It has astonishing architectural beauty and also stands as a symbol of faith, religion, culture and tradition. Pashupatinath Temple's existence dates back to 400 A.D. It’s also known as 'The Temple of Living Beings'. Thousands of devotees from within and outside the country come to worship to Pashupatinath every day.It’s Beautiful and you can see lots of old architecture, which will make u spellbound. I sawGold-painted images of guardian deities, Chaturmukha (four-faced statue), Chadeshvar, an inscribed Licchavi linga from the 7th century, Brahma Temple, Dharmashila, a stone where sacred oaths are taken, Arya Ghat, Gauri Ghat (holy bath), Pandra Shivalaya (15 shrines), Gorakhnath and Vishwarup Temples, Guhyeshwari (Guhjeshwari) Temple, Kirateshwar Mahadeva Mandir and Surya Ghat.

One of our favorite sights on our trip. We spent quite a bit of time in the square soaking in the atmosphere. Lunch overlooking the temple was amazing. Such a great place. We did have a problem with an especially aggressive beggar, but other than that, it was a splendid stop!

World Heritage Site of Nepal. Kathmandu's royal palace, known as the Hanuman Dhoka, was originally founded during the Licchavi period (4th to 8th centuries AD) but the compound was expanded considerably by King Pratap Malla in the 17th century. Sadly, the sprawling palace was hit hard by the 2015 earthquake and damage was extensive. At the time of research, the palace was closed for reconstruction, but once this work is complete, visitors should again be able to access the beautiful royal courtyards and royal museum.Even from the outside, the palace is impressive. Hanuman’s assistance to the noble Rama during the exciting events of the Ramayana has led to the monkey god’s appearance guarding many important entrances. Here, cloaked in red and sheltered by an umbrella, a Hanuman statue marks the dhoka (entrance) to the Hanuman Dhoka and has even given the palace its name. The statue dates from 1672; the god’s face has long disappeared under a coating of orange vermillion paste applied by generations of devotees.
Kathmandu Durbar Square Sightseeing. I have visited Kathmandu Durbar Square Sightseeing after earthquake there is no any problems to sightseeing aroun Hanuman Dhoka area thanks.
beautiful temple. One of the beautiful temple in kathmandu. Old and well maintained. At darbar square, a must visit place of kathmandu

renowned beautiful archecture. what can one say it is so different....walk up the 36 or so steep steps and look down at the square which is filled with locals visiting and enjoy by sitting and have a coffee and people watch
wonderful place to visit. this is a ancient place which was is beautiful place and i had visited this place by @Rosha Trek & Expedition P. Ltd.
Good One. These are excellent sightseeing activity; All paces of historic importance collectively placed and each one speaks rich about the ancient customs and traditions in Nepal

Fascinating Window into Ancient Kathmandu. The Hanuman Dhoka and the Kathmandu Durbar Square that houses Hanuman Dhoka provides a fascinating and interesting glimpse insights into the history of Kathmandu. Note that Kathmandu used to a kingdom by itself centuries back and thus had its own unique culture and tradition, some of which is visible here through the temples, shrines, architecture and historical structures and monuments. The Durbar Square houses palaces and structures belonging to rules of multiple dynasties that ruled Kathmandu. This place is also popular for all kinds of and all price ranges of Nepali souvenirs - depends on how good of a bargainer you are!There is entrance fee to the region for tourists like USD 10, and personal guides cost around 15-20 USD (again depends on how good of a bargainer you are), but totally worth it and definitely recommended! Make sure the guides are licensed by the government and speak good English - most are and most do. They will be able to provide you with history and hidden significance of each palace, shrine, architecture, or ritual performed there. The guide tour usually lasts an hour and half to two hours or longer if you wish. After the tour is over, just take a stroll exploring the fascinating bazaars and interesting culture, get lost in the crowded alleys and discover more of Kathmandu! Most important thing, it is absolutely safe there, especially for tourists, Kathmandu being the city of people actually practicing good hospitality!

All gone. So sad to visit this place as i have visited 2 years back as it was so proudly standing in pride. Its a museum part of Hanuman Dhoka. The palace got its name from the image of Hanuman. Its still firm standing up there even the surroundings has touch down the ground. The great Hanuman. Its a great place to visit and no one must miss it if you are in nepal. Its so unique by itself no words to express.

DEmolished?. Have seen this been demolished by the earthquake. One of the Nepalese prides. The whole place was a paradise for people who are interested in history , architecture and photography. It was a busy place. Even many Nepalese tend to visit here in thousand everyday. But now, no idea?
Impressive. Has suffered a bit of damage from the recent earthquake. Worth visiting. Probably best to have a guide to explain the various structures and the history

Gone. There is nothing left of this stupa, just the base. It is not worthwhile paying the entrance to see nothing.
